Description: Contains an invisible protocol sniffer for finding vulnerabilities in the network, designed for pentesters and security professionals,It is based entirely on network traffic analysis, so it does not make any noise on the air. Above allows pentesters to automate the process of finding vulnerabilities in network hardware. Discovery protocols, dynamic routing, FHRP, STP, LLMNR/NBT-NS, etc.

Specify the interface
Specify the output pcap file to record traffic
Specify the timer value (seconds)
Specify the input pcap file to analyze traffic

Output to 'dir'.afd (can only convert one at a time). Consider AFF if file ends using .aff. Otherwise assumes raw. The directory must have .afd as extension in name.

Usage.description: To have aircrack-ng conduct a WEP key attack on a capture file, pass it the filename, either in .ivs or .cap/.pcap format. Aircrack-ng 1.4
Specify the wordlist to use (-w password.lst) and the path to the capture file (wpa.cap) containing at least one 4-way handshake.

Commands.description: Specify the input file to use.
Specify the output file to generate.
Specify the graph type.

Usage.description: Specify the input file to use (-i dump-01.csv), the output file to generate (-o capr.png) and the graph type (-g CAPR):
Creating your Graph using, dump-01.csv and writing to, cpg.png
Parse the provided capture files (wpa-psk-linksys.cap wpa.cap) and save any 4-way handshakes to a new file (/root/handshakes.cap):
Use the specified monitor mode interface (-i wlan0mon) and target a single BSSID (-v de:ad:be:ef:ca:fe)
Specify a BSSID (-b de:ad:be:ef:ca:fe), WEP key (-k 123456789ABCDEF123456789AB), and output filename (-w makeivs.ivs)
Testing the Cracked File for data
Strip out the initialization vectors of the provided .pcap capture and save them to a new file
Merge multiple IVS files into a single IVS file named 'all-ivs.ivs' located in the '/root' directory.
Run the buddy-ng tool.

Launch the Easside-ng attack with the following options:
- Set the victim MAC address to 'de:ad:be:ef:ca:fe'.
- Set the MAC address of the access point to '3c:46:d8:4e:ef:aa'.
- Set the source IP address to '127.0.0.1'.
- Use the wireless interface 'wlan0mon'.
- Set the channel to '6'.

Launch the besside-ng attack with the following options:
- Attack WPA only.
- Display verbose output.
- Use monitor mode interface 'wlan0mon'.
Specify the BSSID of the access point to monitor as 'DE:AD:BE:EF:CA:FE' and its WEP key as '1234567890'. Then execute the airtun-ng tool using the monitor mode interface 'wlan0mon'.
Start a server instance on port 4444 using the monitor mode interface 'wlan0mon' on channel 6.
Specify the name of the database 'airolib-db' to use and import a file containing the ESSIDs of the network(s) targeted from '/root/essid.txt'. If the database does not exist, it will be created.
Import any wordlists to use for PMK computation into the 'airolib-db' database.
Use the '--batch' option to compute all PMKs for the networks stored in the 'airolib-db' database.
Use the airolib-ng database with aircrack-ng by specifying the database name 'airolib-db' using the '-r' option when cracking the WPA key from the capture file '/root/wpa.cap'.

Usage.mode: Monitor all wireless networks, frequency hopping between all wireless channels

Sniff on channel 6 via monitor mode interface wlan0mon and save the capture to a file named 'chan6' in the '/root' directory.

Usage.description: Filter for access points by a specific manufacturer with the OUI 'FC:15:B4' and mask 'FF:FF:FF:00:00:00' on the wlan0mon interface.

Usage.mode: Enable monitor mode on a wireless interface
Usage.description: Enable monitor mode on the 'wlan0' interface, fixed on channel 6. A new interface 'wlan0mon' will be created.

Usage.mode: Stop monitor mode on a wireless interface
Usage.description: Destroy the monitor mode interface 'wlan0mon' and place the wireless interface 'wlan0' back into managed mode.

Launch the besside-ng attack with the following options:
- Attack WPA only.
- Display verbose output.
- Use monitor mode interface 'wlan0mon'.

Usage.description: Run the injection test (-9) via the monitor mode interface wlan0mon to check if injection is working.

Run the deauthentication attack (-0), sending 5 packets to the wireless access point '8C:7F:3B:7E:81:B6' to deauthenticate a wireless client '00:08:22:B9:41:A1' via the monitor mode interface wlan0mon.

Run the fake authentication attack and re-authenticate every 6000 seconds (-1 6000) against the access point 'F0:F2:49:82:DF:3B' with the ESSID 'FBI-Van-24', specifying the MAC address '3c:46:d8:4e:ef:aa', using the monitor mode interface wlan0mon.

Commands.description: Set the Access Point MAC address for the attack.
Capture packets from the specified interface.
Use the specified WEP key to encrypt or decrypt packets.
Set the source MAC address for MITM (Man-in-the-Middle) mode.
Disallow specified client MAC addresses (by default, clients are allowed).
Set or don't set the WEP flag in beacons. '0' means don't set, '1' means set. By default, it is set automatically.
Quiet mode. Suppress printing of statistics.
Verbose mode. Print more messages for debugging or informational purposes.
Ad-Hoc Mode. Allows other clients to peer.
Specify external packet processing direction: incoming, outgoing, or both.
Set the channel on which the Access Point is running.
Set the hidden ESSID mode.
Force shared key authentication.
Set shared key challenge length. By default, it is set to 128.
Activate the Caffe-Latte WEP attack mode. Use this if the driver cannot send frags.
Activate the cfrag WEP attack mode. Recommended for WEP attacks.
Set the number of packets per second. By default, it is set to 100.
Disable responses to broadcast probes.
Set all WPA, WEP, open tags. This option can't be used with -z and -Z.
Set WPA1 tags. Available types: 1=WEP40, 2=TKIP, 3=WRAP, 4=CCMP, 5=WEP104.
Set WPA2 tags. Same as -z, but for WPA2.
Specify the fake EAPOL type. Available types: 1=MD5, 2=SHA1, 3=auto.
Write all sent and received frames into a pcap file with the specified prefix.
Respond to all probes, even when specifying ESSIDs.
Set the beacon interval value in milliseconds.
Enable beaconing of probed ESSID values. Requires -P option.
Specify a user-specified ANonce when doing the 4-way handshake.

Usage.description: The Hirte attack attempts to retrieve a WEP key via a client. This command creates an access point on channel 6 (-c 6) with the specified ESSID 'TotallyNotATrap'. It uses the cfrag WEP attack (-N) and sets the WEP flag in the beacons (-W 1) on the monitor mode interface wlan0mon.

Usage.mode: Caffe Latte Attack - Access Point Mode
Usage.description: The Caffe Latte Attack attempts to retrieve a WEP key via a client. This command creates an access point on channel 6 (-c 6) with the specified ESSID 'AlsoNotATrap'. It uses the Caffe Latte WEP attack (-L) and sets the WEP flag in the beacons (-W 1) on the monitor mode interface wlan0mon.

Commands.description: Don't remove the 802.11 header.
Filter by access point MAC address.
Specify the target network SSID.
Specify the output file for decrypted packets. Default: <src>-dec.
Specify the target network WEP key in hexadecimal.
Specify the output file for corrupted WEP packets. Default: <src>-bad.
Specify the target network WPA passphrase.
Specify the WPA Pairwise Master Key in hexadecimal.

Usage.description: With a given ESSID 'test' and password 'biscotte', decrypt the specified WPA capture file 'wpa.cap'. This command attempts to decrypt the WPA packets using the provided ESSID and password.
Verify the decryption of the WPA capture by reading the decrypted capture file 'wpa-dec.cap' using tcpdump. This command reads the decrypted packets after attempting decryption with airdecap-ng.
